According to the Armed Conflict Location and Event Data (ACLED) project, more than 1,300 civilians were deliberately killed by ethnic Fulani militias from January - July 2018.  These are deliberate killings by an ethnic Fulani,  Muslim militias that selectively target non-Fulani ethnic groups (such as Tiv and Bachama) who are also Christian.  Many of the attacks are large scale and are launched against three, four, five, or more villages simultaneously.   While the exact militia motivations and leaders are unknown, it does appear to be a systematic attempt to permanently remove non-Fulani, non-Muslim farmers from prime grazing land. This looks like a pretty clear positive resolution for the prior version of this question, and if trends continue going forward, the 1,000 fatality threshold could easily be surpassed again.

The majority of deaths in Nigeria occur in Borno State. Although the Nigerian government indicates that Boko Haram have been neutralized, sources indicate that Boko Haram killed 900 people in 2017, slightly more than they did in 2016 (BBC), and the CFR report that Borno State had 1,940 deaths reported over the same period of time - July 2016 to June 2017 - last year (CFR). Since we do not know the nature of the deaths reported, i.e. whether a result of intentional civilian targeting, I have to assess my probability relatively low, while taking into account the indiscriminate terrorist attacks of Boko Haram that continue in highly civilian congested markets, towns, city centers and even IDP camps (such as in Maiduguri and Durumi IDP camp, July 2017 IDP camp attacks).  Furthermore, BBC's account of 900 deaths in 2017, take into account deaths in Boko Haram territories in Nigeria, Cameroon, Niger and Chad. However, the largest death tolls are reported in Nigeria, and this is taken into account in my probability assessment.  I have taken into account that as Boko Haram continues it's campaign of civilian targeting, the likelihood of state military action increases, and the Nigerian state has a history of indiscriminate civilian killing as well as extrajudicial killing.  https://www.cfr.org/nigeria/nigeria-security-tracker/p29483 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-42735414 https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/thousands-displaced-boko-haram-languish-abuja-idp-camps-180325070133915.html
